case_name: Lalji Raj and sons of Bankura v. Hansraj Nathu Ram

facts.text: Decree-holders obtained a decree against the respondents in the court of Sub-Judge, Bankura West Bengal for a sum of over Rs. 12,000/- on December 3, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The decree-holders obtained a decree against the respondents in the companyrt of Sub-Judge, Bankura  West Bengal  for a sum of over Rs. 12,000/-, on December 3, 1949.

facts.text: Decree-holders applied to the court which passed the decree to transfer the decree to the court at Morena in the then Madhya Bharat State for execution on March 28, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On March 28, 1950 they applied to the companyrt which passed the decree to transfer the decree together with a certificate of number-satisfaction to the companyrt at Morena in the then Madhya Bharat State for execution.

facts.text: Execution proceedings commenced in the court of Additional District Judge at Morena on September 21, 1950 as Money Execution Case No. 8 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The execution proceedings companymenced in the companyrt of Additional District Judge at Morena on September 21, 1950  Money Execution Case No. 8 of 1950 .

facts.text: Judgment-debtors resisted execution claiming court had no jurisdiction as decree was of a foreign court and passed ex parte; court dismissed execution petition on December 29, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment-debtors resisted the execution on the ground that the companyrt had numberjurisdiction to execute the same as the decree was that of a foreign companyrt and that the same had been passed exparte. The companyrt accepted that companytention and dismissed the execution petition on December 29, 1950.

facts.text: Code of Civil Procedure Amendment Act, Act 11 of 1951 came into force on April 1, 1951, extending the Code to former State of Madhya Bharat.

anchor.surface_text: On April 1, 1951 the Code of Civil Procedure  Amendment  Act,  Act 11 of 1951  came into force. As a result of that the Code of Civil Procedure  in short the Code  was extended to the former State of Madhya Bharat as well as to various other places.

facts.text: Decree-holders appealed the dismissal order of Additional District Judge Morena to Madhya Pradesh High Court, which allowed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile the decree-holders appealed against the order of the learned Additional District Judge, Morena dismissing the execution petition, to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh. The Madhya Pradesh High Court allowed their appeal.

facts.text: Judgment-debtors appealed MP HC order to Supreme Court, which allowed the appeal and restored the order of Additional District Judge Morena on April 30, 1962, reported as Hansraj Nathu Ram v. Lalji Raj and sons of Bankura.

anchor.surface_text: As against that the judgment debtors appealed to this Court. This Court allowed the appeal of the judgment- debtors and restored the order of the learned Additional District Judge,, Morena. The decision of this Court is reported in Hansraj Nathu Ram v. Lalji Raj and sons of Bankura 1 . Therein this Court ruled that the transfer ordered by  1  1963 2 S.C.R. 619. the Bankura companyrt was without jurisdiction as on that date the Code did number apply to the Morena companyrt

facts.text: Supreme Court held in Hansraj case that transfer by Bankura court was without jurisdiction as Code did not apply to Morena court then.

anchor.surface_text: This Court held that Morena companyrt number being a companyrt to which the, Code apple, the decree companyld number have been transport to it It further bed that ss. 38 and 39 of the Code did number afford jurisdiction for such a transfer.

facts.text: Decree-holders filed another execution case before Bankura court on February 15, 1963, praying for transfer to Morena court.

anchor.surface_text: On February 15, 1963, the decree holders filed another exe- cution case before the Bankura companyrt. Therein they prayed for the transfer of the decree again to the Morena companyrt for execution.

facts.text: Bankura court ordered transfer of decree to Morena court again.

anchor.surface_text: As numbericed earlier, by that time the Code had been extended to the Madhya Bharat State which had become a part of the State of Madhya Pradesh. The Bankura companyrt again ordered the mans fer of the decree to the Morena companyrt.

facts.text: Execution proceedings started afresh in Morena court on August 31, 1963 as Execution Case No. 1 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The execution proceedings were started afresh in the Morena companyrt on August 31, 1963  Execution Case No. 1 of 1963 .

facts.text: Judgment-debtors resisted execution claiming: barred by res judicata, s.48 Code, limitation, decree not executable as foreign court decree.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment-debt- resisted the execution on various grounds viz.  a  that it is barred by res-judicata in view of the decision of this Court referred to earlier-,  b  that it is barred by s. 48. of the. Code  c  that it is barred by limitation and  d  that the decree is number executable as it is a decree of a foreign companyrt.

facts.text: Additional District Judge rejected judgment-debtors' objections.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional District Judge rejected the objections raised by the judgment-debtors.

facts.text: Judgment-debtors appealed to Madhya Pradesh High Court, which held execution not barred by res judicata, s.48 or limitation, but decree not executable as foreign court decree, dated August 27, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 27, 1964 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 20 of 1964.

facts.text: Decree-holders filed appeal by special leave to Supreme Court as Civil Appeal No. 2427 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2427 of1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 27, 1964 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Appeal No. 20 of 1964.

facts.text: Decree was ex parte; judgment-debtors served with notice but did not appear.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment with which we are companycerned in this case was an ex-parse judgment. The Bankura companyrt had numberjurisdiction over the judgment-debtors. The Judgment-debtors did number submit themselves to the jurisdiction of that companyrt though they were served with a numberice of the suit.

facts.text: Cause of action for the suit arose within jurisdiction of Bankura court.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute in this case that the cause of action for the suit which led up to the decree under execution arose within the jurisdiction of Bankura companyrt.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Bankura court not a foreign court under CPC definitions.

anchor.surface_text: Whether we take the earlier definition or the present definition into companysideration the Bankura companyrt, cannot be companysidered as a foreign companyrt within the meaning of that expression in the Code.

facts.text: Supreme Court held decree not barred by s.48 CPC, as previous proceedings prosecuted with due diligence and good faith, infructuous for want of jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Both the executing companyrt as well as the High Court have taken the view that on the facts of this case, the limitation prescribed in s. 48 of the Co is extended under S. 14 2  of the Limitation Act, 1908.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court order, restored trial court order, directed execution to proceed.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons mentioned above this appeal is allowed and the order of the High Court is set aside and that of the trial companyrt restored. The executing companyrt is directed to proceed with the execution.

holdings.text: the Bankura court, cannot be considered as a foreign court within the meaning of that expression in the Code.

anchor.surface_text: Whether we take the earlier definition or the present definition into consideration the Bankura court, cannot be considered as a foreign court within the meaning of that expression in the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory definition of 'foreign court' in s.2(5) CPC, both pre- and post-1951 amendment, excludes Bankura court situated in British India/West Bengal under Central Government authority.

holdings.text: the decree under execution cannot be considered as a foreign decree for the purpose of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: Foreign judgment is defined in the Code as the judgment of a foreign court. S. 2 6 of the Code . Hence the decree under execution cannot be considered as a foreign decree for the purpose of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from s.2(6) defining foreign judgment as one of foreign court; since Bankura not foreign, decree not foreign.

holdings.text: as the judgment in question cannot be considered as a judgment of a foreign court, they can take no assistance from s. 13 b.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.13 applies only to foreign judgments; not applicable here.

holdings.text: there is no basis for the contention that any principle of natural justice had been contravened.

holdings.text: the decree under execution is not a foreign decree and its transfer to the Morena court is in accordance with the provisions of the Code.

precedents.citation: Sirdar Gurdval Singh v. The Rajah of Faridkote 1 ... 1 . 21 I.A. 171.

anchor.surface_text: Sirdar Gurdval Singh v. The Rajah of Faridkote 1 . Therein the Judicial Committee observed In a personal action, to which numbere of these causes of jurisdiction apply, a decree pronounced in absentem by a foreign Court, to the jurisdiction of which the Defendant has number in any way submitted himself, is by international law an absolute nullity. But the Board qualified those observations by the following words He is under numberobligation of any kind to obey it and it must be regarded as a mere nullity by the Courts  1 . 21 I.A. 171.

anchor.surface_text: From the foregoing discussion., it follows that the decree under execution is number a foreign decree and its transfer to the Morena court is in accordance with the provisions of the Code. That being so, the decree under execution satisfies the dictum of this Court in Hansraj Nathu Ram v. Lalji Raja and sons 1  that a decree can be executed by a court which passed the decree or to which it was transferred for execution and the decree which could be transferred has to be a decree Passed under the Code and the Court to which it could be transferred has to be a Court which was governed by the Indian Code of Civil Procedure. It was next urged on behalf of the judgment-debtor that in view of the decision of this Court in Shitoles cave  supra  we must hold that the decree is a nullity and that it cannot be executed at all in the courts situate in the former State of Madhya Bharat. In Shitoles case  sunra  this Court was called upon to consider a converse case.  1  19632 S.C.R. 619.  2  19632 S.C.R. 577.

anchor.surface_text: That a provision to preserve the right accrued under a repealed Act was number intended to preserve the abstract rights conferred by the repealed Act It only applies to specific rights given to an individual upon happening of one or the other of the events specified in statute case Lord Atkins observations in Hamilton Gell v. White 1 . The mere right. existing at the date of repealing statute to take advantage of provisions of the statute repealed is number a right accrued within the meaning of the usual saving clause-see Abbot v. Minister for lands  2   and G. Ogden Industries Pty. Ltd. v. Lucas 3 .  1 1922 2 K.B. 422.

precedents.cited_proposition: provision to preserve accrued right under repealed Act applies only to specific rights, not abstract rights

precedents.citation: Abbot v. Minister for lands 2 1895 A.C. 425.

anchor.surface_text: The mere right. existing at the date of repealing statute to take advantage of provisions of the statute repealed is number a right accrued within the meaning of the usual saving clause-see Abbot v. Minister for lands  2   and G. Ogden Industries Pty. Ltd. v. Lucas 3 . From what has been said above, it follows that the view taken by the High Court that the decree in question is a nullity qua the Morena court cannot be accented as correct.  2 1895 A.C. 425.
